Derek James wrote:

>On Thu, 03 Jun 2004 20:30:04 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
><kstanley@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>I also think "bloat" is a misnomer here.  Bloat is a term from
>>Genetic Programming that referred to the accumulation of extraneous
>>structure over the *entire population* that didn't help improve
>>fitness.  In general they were looking at a situaton where everyone
>>was getting bigger for no good reason.
>>    
>>
>
>Well, this is something we've discussed before, and I'm not sure we're
>going to come to a consensus on the issue.  But I'd argue that "bloat"
>is an appropriate term to use if the *average* complexity of the
>population is increasing unnecessarily.
>  
>
I agree with that, but we disagree about what structures are unnecessary.

>You say that I was only describing a situation where the mutation
>rates are too high.  Well, wouldn't you term that bloat?  If you take
>a simple problem and apply NEAT to it, and have two runs, one where
>the mutation rates are double the other, NEAT will still solve the
>problem.  By the end of both runs, there will be a range of
>complexity, as you describe.  There will be complex networks and
>simple networks.  But in the run with doubled mutation rates, both the
>*average* complexity and the complexity of the champion will be
>unnecessarily higher.
>
>You would consider this bloat, wouldn't you? 
>  
>
Consider the problem from the other direction then. If all of of these 
useless structures aren't participating positively in a search (on the 
whole) then every single improvement seen in a population must come from 
immediately beneficial single mutations. So if at the end of a run I 
take the champion and trace back through its ancestors I will see a 
steady line of single improvements, each of which *immediately* improved 
the fitness and ultimately resulted in the champion. And *every* neuron 
that was added in this ancestoral line was immediately beneficial by way 
of the non-linearity it introduced. I just can't see that this would be 
the case...

[quote from previous post]

>But again, if we're just talking about a single neuron, why not just
>allow for a single mutation to bring about that new functionality,
>instead of keeping redundant features around, waiting for them to be
>connected?  The former is much more efficient than the latter.
>
Ok but this is what happens now. What I'm saying is that that neuron 
won't always become immediately beneficial. As connection mutations 
occur in later generations we then try connecting that neuron to other 
(already existing/functional) neurons, this searching through possible 
connections could then result in an improvement in fitness that 
capitalises on the non-linearity of the new neuron. As you're going 
about this search you're going to create some junk and spin off new, 
more complex species with junk in them, but I see that as a necessary 
part of the search process - if you don't try these structures you'll 
just get stuck because there may not be any one mutation that can get 
you out of the local optimum. This is why I was refering to jumps in 
evolution and the importance of smooth fitness functions instead of 
large steps, a nice smooth function allows you to make small incremental 
mutations towards building a champion genome, but if there are steps, 
even small ones, then you need some degree of 'blind-faith' in your 
search strategy in order to get out of the local optimum.

I'm reminded of past arguments that creationists have used against 
evolution,  it goes something like - "I can't see how some biological 
structures came about because they seem like too much of a jump, there 
doesn't seem to be any possible gradual evolutionary steps that produced 
certain structures. therefore they were designed."  I think this is 
because sometimes jumps are made, so e.g. a piece of  DNA that codes for 
a single protein might get accidentally copied into part of the genome 
that describes high-level morphology and instead of describing a protein 
it now describes, say, a vibration sensitive hair. It's not at all very 
sensitive, but better than nothing since it allows you to detect your 
noisy predators! Now, gradual incremental mutations can improve on that 
hair and over time produce a cochlea and with the help of a few other 
little jumps - a complete ear.

So anyway, what I was proposing was a method of getting the best of both 
worlds. If excess structure is important then keep it, but if the search 
has stagnated for a period of time then I would say that the excess 
structures have now had plenty of time to prove themselves - and failed. 
They have crossed the line from being possible useful structures into 
being useless junk (bloat). So I propose switching the search into trim 
mode, once this has settled down (genomes no longer getting smaller) we 
resume the normal search, building up excess structures once again.

Colin
